entry.title: Moscow and Baku exchange tense statements over Karabakh place names, as fears of new conflict grow

media:group.media:title: Moscow and Baku exchange tense statements over Karabakh place names, as fears of new conflict grow
media:group.media:description:
üìçSince late last week, Russia‚Äôs and Azerbaijan‚Äôs Defense Ministries have exchanged a series of tense statements over place names in Karabakh, as fears of a new round of conflict in the region, this time over the crucial Lachin corridor, continue to grow. üìçAt the same time, Baku and Stepanakert continue exchanging a near daily stream of ceasefire violation accusations, mirroring previous patterns, where spikes in such accusations presaged Azerbaijani attacks on Karabakh Armenian positions.
Credits: Ruptly

entry.title: Armenia and the EU market: Breaking down myths, promoting trade

media:group.media:title: Armenia and the EU market: Breaking down myths, promoting trade
media:group.media:description:
The European Union is Armenia‚Äôs second largest trade partner, after only Russia. Karen Azaryan, trade officer at the European Union delegation to Armenia, sat down with CivilNet‚Äôs Mark Dovich to discuss common misconceptions about the EU market‚Äôs accessibility, the prospects for Armenian companies looking to ramp up exports to Europe, and Brussels‚Äô support for small and medium sized-businesses in Armenia.

entry.title: What needs to happen for the Armenian nation to regroup and remobilize?

media:group.media:title: What needs to happen for the Armenian nation to regroup and remobilize?
media:group.media:description:
James Tufenkian, the founder of the Tufenkian Foundation, sat down with writer and economist Vahan Zanoyan to discuss his Armenian roots and what motivated him to create the foundation. Tufenkian also talks about how the foundation‚Äôs projects were affected by the 2020 Karabakh war and how Armenia can navigate the region‚Äôs difficult geopolitics.

entry.title: Fears of new attack as Aliyev threatens to forcibly open corridor through Armenia

media:group.media:title: Fears of new attack as Aliyev threatens to forcibly open corridor through Armenia
media:group.media:description:
Worries of a new escalation of conflict and a large-scale military attack by Azerbaijan have been raised after Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev said Armenia will not be able to stop the opening of the so-called ‚ÄúZangezur corridor‚Äù through its territory. Those comments have led some observers to speculate that Aliyev may order new military aggression in order to forcibly open an overland corridor through southern Armenia.
